Award.AwardTitle: An Investigation of the Dynamic and Thermodynamic Processes that Lead to Distinctly Different Pathways to Tropical Cyclogenesis
Award.AbstractNarration:
The formation of tropical storms and hurricanes, known as tropical cyclogenesis, is a complex process involving interactions between the large-scale environment and a smaller-scale atmospheric disturbance passing through. There have been multiple theories developed to try to describe the pathway that a disturbance takes on its road to becoming a tropical storm. In this project, researchers will use advanced, high-resolution numerical modeling to analyze the processes involved in two of these pathways. Improved knowledge of how tropical cyclones form will aid forecasters and improve public safety, especially in the cases where small storms develop very close to populated areas. This award will also provide a training opportunity for a graduate student.

The first pathway to tropical cyclogenesis is characterized by a spin up of cyclonic surface winds and vorticity building in the center of deep convective towers. The second is characterized by a mid-level vortex that is followed by a small surface concentrated vortex near the center of the large scale circulation. The research plan is to conduct idealized numerical experiments using the Regional Atmospheric Modeling System (RAMS) with new riming and surface flux schemes and the Weather Research and Forecasting (WRF) model with moving nested grids. The main objectives that the project will address are to: 1) Determine the physical mechanisms responsible for the development of strong mid-level vortices and the conditions that favor their occurrence, 2) Identify the processes leading to the formation of a small surface concentrated vortex, and 3) Determine the effect of vertical wind shear, including a mean flow, on the pathway taken to tropical cyclogenesis.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The problem of how hurricanes form is an extremely complex one and the ability to forecast which tropical disturbances will develop into these dangerous life threatening storms remains a serious challenge. This project focused on furthering understanding of several physical processes that have been identified as important for hurricane formation using sophisticated computer model simulations that are able to explicitly represent cloud processes. One of the characteristics of hurricane formation is that a strong circulation, or vortex, often forms a few kilometers above the surface in the tropical disturbance prior to strengthening of the surface winds. A task of this study was to determine the reasons why this mid-level vortex developed. It was found that it develops after merging of numerous anvils from deep convective cells creates an extensive canopy of ice crystals aloft. As these ice crystals grow and fall to middle levels they undergo sublimation, which is a change of phase from ice to vapor. This cools the air at mid levels causing it to become negatively buoyant and sink. As this cooled air sinks it causes air to be drawn in laterally to replace it.  This mid-level inflow generates the mid-level vortex since the effect of the Earth’s rotation, known as the Coriolis force, turns winds to the right in the northern hemisphere producing a cyclonic circulation.

    A very important aspect of the formation of a mid-level vortex is that it puts the brakes on the development of the surface circulation. For instance, if the model cloud microphysics does not include the ice phase then a mid-level vortex will not form and the simulation will develop a hurricane much quicker. Therefore, this study shows that it is crucial for operational computer hurricane models to correctly represent ice phase microphysics otherwise forecasts may erroneously predict development of the system.

    Another focus of this research effort was to determine why strong small scale vortices often form at low levels in the model simulations. These have a horizontal scale of about ten kilometers, so are significantly larger than tornadoes and while fairly intense they have much weaker winds in comparison. Typically one of these small vortices will form at some distance from the center of the larger scale circulation and then spiral inwards rapidly strengthening once it reached the center. Within a short time this small vortex intensifies into a tropical storm. It was found that these small vortices characteristically formed at the edges of spreading surface cold pools, or at the intersection of colliding cold pools. It is well known that convective storms develop downdrafts due to evaporative cooling of rain and when this cold air reaches the surface an outflow occurs. In the large scale cyclonic winds of the developing tropical disturbance these cold pools form strong horizontal wind shears at their edges. New convective cells at the edges of these cold pools converge the winds in these strongly sheared regions, which causes small vortices to form. The complicated details of this process were analyzed. Moreover it was shown how a small vortex once formed could maintain itself by subsequent vortex mergers thereby enabling it to reach the center.

    Tropical cyclogenesis usually occurs in environments that have winds that change with height, which is referred to as vertical wind shear. Strong vertical wind shear is known to be detrimental for tropical cyclogenesis. Computer simulations were conducted to examine the effect of various values of shear on the structure of the system and the rate of development. It was found that pronounced structural asymmetries occurred. For instance for cases that developed a strong mid-level vortex it was located downshear and to the left of the low level circulation center. Even for weak shears the mid-level vortex center was often 100 km or more distant from the low-level circulation center. The strongest convection tended to occur downshear and the cold pools they produced which were moved by the low-level cyclonic winds accumulated on the downshear left side of the system. The convective storms were fueled mainly by moist and warm air from the downshear right side with strong convergence and uplift occurring when they encountered the cold surface air. Tropical cyclogenesis occurred when the low-level and mid-level circulations became vertically aligned. These results demonstrate that the pathway to tropical cyclogenesis in shear can be significantly different than when there is no shear.

    This study has contributed to unraveling the complex dynamic and thermodynamic processes that occur in the early stages of hurricane formation. Understanding these processes will enable a better evaluation of the most effective observations that need to be made and the crucial model physics that need to be implemented in order to improve operational forecasts of these dangerous weather systems. This will allow more time for communities to prepare in advance of approaching storms.
